DIR-SECTION.HEADING: The Constitution
DIR-SECTION.P: The Constitution of the Principality of Andorra came into force on 4 May 1993, having been approved by the Andorran people in a referendum on 14 March. The official name of the independent state is Principat d’Andorra. The Constitution asserts that Andorra is ’a Democratic and Social independent state abiding by the Rule of Law’, defines the fundamental rights, freedoms and obligations of Andorran citizens and delineates the functions and competences of the organs of state.
In accordance with Andorran tradition, the Coprínceps (Co-Princes), respectively the Bishop of Urgell and the President of the French Republic, serve jointly as head of state.

The legislature is the Consell General (General Council ), which comprises between 28 and 42 members. Two members of the General Council are elected to represent each of Andorra’s seven Parròquies (parishes), and one-half are elected from a single national constituency by a system of proportional representation; members are elected to the General Council for four years (or until the dissolution of the General Council). Elections are on the basis of direct universal adult suffrage. The ruling organ of the General Council is the Sindicatura, headed by a Síndic General (Speaker).

The Govern (the executive organ of state) is directed by the Cap de Govern (Head of Government), who is elected by the General Council (and formally appointed by the Co-Princes) and who must command the support of the majority of the legislature’s members. The Head of Government nominates government ministers, who may not at the same time be members of the General Council. The Head of Government is restricted to two consecutive full terms of office.
The Constitution defines the composition and powers of the judi­ciary, the highest organ of which is the Consell Superior de Justícia (Higher Court of Justice).
The Constitution defines the functions of the Comuns (communal councils), which are the organs of representation and administration of the parishes.

Revision of the Constitution shall require the approval of two-thirds of the members of the General Council and ratification by a referendum. The General Council is advised on constitutional matters by the Institució del Raonador del Ciutadà, an independent institution established in 1998, responsible for the application of the Constitution.
The Constitutional Court is the supreme interpreter of the Constitution. Its decisions are binding for public authorities and for indi­viduals.

DIR-SECTION.HEADING: Govern
DIR-SECTION.P: The executive is formed by the Demòcrates per Andorra (Democrats for Andorra), Liberals d’Andorra (Andorran Liberals) and Ciutadans Compromesos (Committed Citizens).

DIR-SECTION.HEADING: Judicial System
DIR-SECTION.P: Judicial power is vested, in the first instance, in the Batllia (Magistrates’ Courts) and in the Tribunal de Batlles (Judges’ Tribunal), the Tribunal de Corts (criminal law courts) and the Tribunal Superior de la Justícia (Higher Court of Justice). The judiciary is represented, directed and administered by the Consell Superior de la Justícia (Higher Council of Justice), whose five members are appointed for single terms of six years. Final jurisdiction, in constitutional matters, is vested in the Tribunal Constitucional (Constitutional Court), whose four members hold office for no more than two consecutive eight-year terms. In early 2018 it was announced that a new court of arbitration was to be established to assist in the resolution of business conflicts in Andorra.
The 1993 Constitution guarantees the independence of the judi­ciary.

DIR-SECTION.HEADING: Religion
DIR-SECTION.P: More than 90% of the population of Andorra are Roman Catholic. Andorra forms part of the Spanish diocese of Urgell.

DIR-SECTION.HEADING: Railways
DIR-SECTION.P: There are no railways in Andorra. The nearest stations are Ax-les-Thermes, L’Hospitalet and La Tour de Carol, in France (with trains from Toulouse and Perpignan), and Puigcerdà, in Spain, on the line from Barcelona. There is a connecting bus service from all four stations to Andorra.

DIR-SECTION.HEADING: Roads
DIR-SECTION.P: A good road connects the Spanish and French frontiers, passing through Andorra la Vella. The Envalira tunnel, between Andorra and France, was opened in 2002. The Dos Valires tunnel to link Encamp and La Massana opened in 2012. Two companies, Cooperativa Interurbana Andorrana and Grup Montmantell, operate bus services within Andorra.

DIR-SECTION.HEADING: Civil Aviation
DIR-SECTION.P: The Andorra-La Seu d’Urgell airport at La Seu d’Urgell, located in Spanish territory 12 km from the border with Andorra, reopened in 2010 following a redevelopment programme financed jointly by the Andorran, Spanish and Catalan administrations.

DIR-SECTION.HEADING: Tourism

DIR-SECTION.HEADING: Defence
DIR-SECTION.P: Andorra has no defence budget.

DIR-SECTION.HEADING: Education
DIR-SECTION.P: Education is compulsory for children of between six and 16 years of age, and is provided free of charge by Catalan-, French- and Spanish-language schools. (Children educated under the French or Spanish state systems are required to study some Catalan.) Six years of primary education are followed by four years of secondary schooling. University education is undertaken either at the University of Andorra or abroad, mostly in Spain and France. The University of Andorra offers degrees in business administration, education science, nursing and computer science. According to UNESCO figures, in 2011/12 85% of the relevant age-group were enrolled in pre-primary education, 75% in primary and 73% in secondary education. A new baccalaureate examination, which was intended to facilitate direct access for students in the Andorran education system to universities in other European countries, was introduced in 2008. Andorra’s only university, the University of Andorra, offers bachelor and postgraduate degrees. In 2021 some 10.3% of total government expenditure was allocated to education.
